Catalyst development is an important process because it affects all dynamics of systems. Optimum values cannot be found easily while catalyst preparation. Input Variable Effect on Responses (IVER) is a very new multi-objective optimization method. It has been developed to eliminate the disadvantages of the Response Surface Method (RSM). The electrolysis of water is known as green hydrogen production and prevents environmental pollution. Studies have focused on the development of effective anodic and cathodic catalysts to reduce the production cost, which is the biggest handicap of this method. In this study, MnO2 swept by nickel is electrochemically deposited on the graphite-supported material to develop an efficient cathode material. Then, MoO2 and Pt electrochemical deposition are carried out, respectively. The optimal electrochemical deposition current, temperature, and time values for the suspended solution concentration are determined using the IVER optimization method. Consequently, the determined optimal (most efficient) suspended solution concentration for MnO2 was 52 ppm, and the most effective deposition condition for Ni is obtained at 28°C, 96 mA, and 55 s. The electrochemical analyzes of the obtained catalysts are carried out by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and linear sweep voltammetry methods. The surface characterizations of these catalysts are carried out using scanning electron microscope-energy-disperse X-ray, XPS, Raman and X-ray diffractometers techniques. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalyst Electrochemical analysis Green hydrogen Optimization Water electrolysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction While 2020 is remembered for the tragic COVID-19 crisis, it has also been an unprecedented year for the global energy transition and the increasing momentum of hydrogen technology. Many countries have announced strategies to develop hydrogen as a key energy carrier, aligning their outbreak responses with long-term goals. In parallel, many countries and companies have adopted net-zero targets for CO2, and they will materialize this using green hydrogen, known as a clean and environmentally friendly energy carrier [1–5]. However, not all hydrogen production techniques comply with the targets for sustainable, climate-safe energy use and net-zero CO2 emissions. Green hydrogen, which is produced using electrolyzers supported by renewable sources, meets these criteria. Green hydrogen is one of the cornerstones of moving away from fossil fuels and is an energy carrier that can be used in many different applications [6–9]. The use of hydrogen will be very important for sectors such as aviation, international maritime, and heavy industry, where the energy density is high and emissions are the most difficult to reduce. By the end of 2019, only five countries had announced their hydrogen strategies. A year later, about 20 more countries announced, and within months, at least 10 more countries followed that number. Currently, more than 120 countries in total have announced their net-zero emission targets. Industry investors plan to produce at least 25 gigawatts (GW) of electrolyzer capacity for green hydrogen by 2026 [10]. Yet, much faster growth in renewable energy and green hydrogen capacity is needed to meet ambitious climate goals and reduce the rise in average global temperatures. Green hydrogen production has significantly increased from less than 1 MW in 2010 to over 25 MW in 2019 [11]. In addition, the size of the project has increased significantly. Green hydrogen production for the whole world is limited to nearly a hundred facilities with a total electrolyzer capacity of approximately 200 MW [10]. But green hydrogen production has the potential to grow rapidly. Cost is the main obstacle to green hydrogen production. It is currently two to three times more expensive than other production methods. The capital cost of electrolysis has fallen by 60% since 2010, which resulted in the cost of hydrogen falling from the $10 to 15 USD / kg range to as low as $4-6 / kg during this period [12]. There are many strategies to further lower costs and support wider hydrogen adoption. Costs can be reduced through economies of scale, innovation, efficiency gains and improvements in the production of electrolyzers [13–17]. The aim of hydrogen production studies with electrolysis is to develop long-lasting and catalytically efficient catalysts to reduce this cost. The hydrogen production process takes place by a mechanism based on the radical adsorption of hydrogen onto the catalyst surface and subsequent desorption as a molecule. Therefore, combinations of metals that improve the sorption mechanism will also increase hydrogen production. Many metal combinations have been studied in the literature as an alternative to commercial Pt / C catalysts [18–25]. As a noble metal, the use of platinum as the cathode material is quite expensive. Therefore, platinum is used with trace amounts of doping. In addition, metallic nickel, or nickel-doped alloys, are widely used as cathode materials for HER, due to their high corrosion resistance in alkaline environments, although their electrocatalytic effect is not very high [26]. Metal oxides are used in catalyst structures to increase their efficiency. Metal oxides were known as unsuitable materials for hydrogen adsorption due to their poor electrical conductivity. However, in recent studies, metal oxides have proven to be a suitable material for HER reactions since they offer electronic and crystal structure flexibility in physical and chemical terms compared to other metal compounds. Among metal oxides, oxide structures of transition metals are often preferred [27]. Molybdenum (IV) oxide (MoO2) and manganese (IV) oxide (MnO2) were used in this study. The electrocatalysts should own to simultaneously both weak and strong M-H bond for alkaline water electrolyze. According to Pourbaix diagram, the nickel and manganese have strong M-H bond and MoO2 has weak M-H bond. This combination provides efficiency for alkaline electrolyzes. The aim of this study is to develop a new method to find the best catalysts preparation conditions with a new optimization method. To find the best optimization conditions (deposition current, time, temperature, etc…) much more experiments must be done, but our new optimization method provides to decreases the experiment count and finds the best condition. Catalysts that contain nickel, manganese (IV) oxide, molybdenum oxide, and trace amounts of platinum obtained in this study can be replaced Pt/C catalyst in terms of stability and catalytic efficiency. On the other side, it can be used commercially because of the low cost. The elements were chosen using the volcano plot of Zeradjanin et al. [28] to occur the best catalytic combination. 2 Experimental Graphite (C) rods about 10 cm in length were used as support material in the experiments. These rods were isolated with epoxy coating except working side which has surface area of 0.283 cm2. Before each test, the working surface was abraded using emery paper (grit 1200) and then washed with distillated water, ethanol, and distilled water again. 2.1 Nickel deposition All electrochemical depositions were performed by two electrode techniques by a DC power supply (TT-Technic YH-303D). Nickel depositions on C-rods were done with nickel anode. The composition of the nickel bath including of NiCl2.6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 97%), H3BO3 (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 99.5 %), and NiSO4.6H2O (Merck, ≥ 98 %) was given in Table 1 . Three deposition times (10, 60, and 110 s), three temperatures (20, 30, and 40°C), and three currents (4, 50, and 96 mA) were used as deposition parameters to improve a more effective catalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). These parameters were chosen as lowest possible value (bottom), highest possible value (top) and the average of them (medium), according to the 3k Full Factorial Design (FFD). The lowest current was 4 mA, which is limited by power supply as the bottom value. The highest current (top) was 96 mA because the deposited nickel amount was about 1.0 mg cm−2, which was chosen to decrease the price of nickel deposition. 20°C was chosen as bottom because it was room temperature, and 40 °C was performed as the highest temperature (top), which provides energy saving. The lowest deposition time (bottom) was used as 10 s to obtain visible metallic nickel on the surface. The 110 s was chosen as the highest deposition time (top) because the homogeneity on the C surface was not provided after this time. The condition, which were 50 mA, 30 °C, and 60 s, were chosen as the medium data for the full factorial design study, because these are the average values between bottom and top values. 2.2 Ni&MnO2 deposition The MnO2 was dopped on the C surface in-situ nickel deposition because of the metal oxide-metal synergistic effect. According to the FFD method, different amounts of MnO2 (bottom: 0.1, medium:1.9, and top:3.7 mg) were added into nickel bath (Table 1) to co-deposited nickel and MnO2. These amounts of MnO2 were representing 3.0 ppm, 60,0 and 120.0 ppm, respectively, and tried to find optimal value. The highest weight was chosen the prevent of the coagulation. The obtained electrode was called Ni*MnO2. 2.3 MoO2 deposition 100 mL solutions of 0.5 M ammonium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24. 4H2O) and 0.3 M trisodium citrate (Na3C6H5O7) will be prepared. The pH of the solution will be raised to 10 with ammonia. Then, in the two-electrode technique, Ni*MnO2 electrode will be connected to the negative pole of the direct current source, while a graphite electrode will be connected to the positive pole. The current of 3.5 mA cm−2 current density will be passed through the circuit for 5 (bottom), 25 (medium), and 45 (top) min, according to the FFD method. At the end of the deposition, the measurements will be taken after the electrode is washed with water and rinsed. The obtained electrode was typified Ni*MnO2/MoO2 2.4 Platinum deposition The platinum bath was prepared by dissolving 0.12 g of K2PtCl6 in 25 mL of 0.1 M HCl. The Ni*MnO2/MoO2 electrode was immersed in the platinum bath and 3.5 mA cm−2 current was passed through the circuit for 45 s versus the Pt electrode at the positive side using the two-electrode technique. At the end of the deposition, the measurements were taken after the electrode was washed with water and rinsed. The obtained electrode was demonstrated Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt 2.5 Full factorial design Three-level full factorial design (3k FFD) is a well-known and used method in the literature and selected to design the experiments in this study. According to this method, combinations of the independent variable values (Possible lowest values represented by -1, possible highest values represented by +1 and central values represented by 0) are used in experiments, as shown in the Fig. 1 . This method best represents all possible combinations of independent variable values in the experiment while increasing the consumption requirement [29]. 2.5.1 Input Variable Effect on Responses (IVER) IVER is a very new multi-objective optimization method [30]. It has been developed to eliminate the disadvantages of Response Surface Method (RSM), which is the best known and most used multi-objective optimization method in the literature. IVER firstly normalizes the dependent variable values ( Y m ) by distributing them between 0 and 1 as seen in the Eq. (1). (1) N m = { Y m max ( Y m ) , I f max ( Y m ) i s d e s i r e d max ( Y m ) + min ( Y m ) − ( Y m ) max ( Y m ) , I f min ( Y m ) i s d e s i r e d It then performs the optimization for each independent variable separately in the following order, while X n is a unique value of each independent variable. • The maximum values of each normalized dependent variable corresponding to a unique value of the independent variable m a x ( N m f o r X n ) are determined. • The average of these maximum values is recorded as the degree of optimality (optimality value) for the unique independent variable value ( X n ) . • The polynomial curve is plotted through each optimality value of the unique independent variable (Xn). • The independent variable value corresponding the horizontal coordinate of the top point of the curve is determined as the optimal independent variable value. 2.5.2 Histogram Equalization Applied Image Representations (HEAIR) Transforming the data into images and offering optimum region instead of a single optimum value with image processing algorithms is a very effective method that has recently been added to the literature [31]. Thanks to this method, it is possible to avoid the influence of omitted independent variables, which are thought to have little effect on the result. According to this method, the data set is placed between 0 a n d 2 bit depth such that the relative distances of the data do not change. In this case, 0 represents black, 2 bit depth represents white and the values between them represent shades of gray. Then the values with no statistically significant difference between them are represented by a single shade of gray using histogram equalization algorithm. Thus, the values that are not statistically different around the inflection point of the curves are represented by the single shade of gray (black or white), and they clarify the optimum range. In other words, if the maximum value of the data set is the optimal value, the optimality range is represented by the white. If the minimum value of the data set is the optimal value, the optimality range is represented by the black. Since the peak of the curve obtained by the IVER method is optimal, the optimality region will be represented by white in this study. However, if there is not inflection point in the curve (if there is a continuous increase or decrease), the optimal range suggested by this method may be too narrow and the method may not be useful. For a better understanding of the methods (IVER and HEAIR), the plots (graph and image) are presented for the sample data set in Fig. 2 . For this sample data set, the aim is to find the independent variable value that will maximize all dependent variables. As can be seen from the data set, if the value of the independent variable is 0, the maximum values for each of the normalized dependent variables are 0.2, 0.1 and 0.1914. If the independent variable value is 5, the maximum values for all normalized dependent variables are 1. Likewise, if the independent variable value is 10, the maximum values for each of the normalized dependent variables are 0.3, 0.9 and 0.5202. In case of the independent variable is 0, the average of the maximum values is 0.1638. In case of the independent variable is 5, the average of the maximum values is 1. In case of the independent variable is 10, the average of the maximum values is 0.5734. That is, as shown in Fig. 2, if the independent variable is 0, optimality is 0.1638, if the independent variable is 5, optimality is 1, and if the independent variable is 10, optimality is 0.5734. The independent variable value corresponding to the maximum value of the curve (plotted in Fig. 2 with blue colour) passing through these 3 values on the horizontal axis is 5.82. So, the independent variable value that will maximize all dependent variables is 5.82. The histogram equalization applied image representation of the curve indicates that the value of the independent variable can actually be between 4.97 and 6.67. Because the range corresponding to the white colour is between 4.97 and 6.67, and the values in this range of the curve are considered statistically the same. 3 Results and discussion In the first step of the study, the optimal independent variable values were determined by IVER and HEAIR methods for electrochemical nickel deposition experiments. During the nickel deposition experiments, current, time and temperature were independent variables while catalyst resistance and hydrogen evolution currents at 0.3 and 0.5 VRHE overpotentials were dependent variables. The aim of the optimization was to maximize the hydrogen evolution currents while minimizing the catalyst resistance. Independent variable values selected to use in experiments were 4, 50, and 96 mA for deposition current, 10, 60, and 110 s for deposition time and 20, 30, and 40 °C for deposition temperature, according to the 3k FFD method. Optimality curves obtained by the IVER method according to the combinations of these selected values and their histogram equalization applied image representations are shown in Fig. 3 . As can be seen from figure, the optimal independent variable value ranges represented by white are 95.9 – 96 mA for deposition current, 49 - 63 s for deposition time, and 25.5–30.5 °C for deposition temperature. Optimal values can be selected as any of the values represented by the white colour in Fig. 3. For safer results, the optimal values of the independent variables as a result of experiment and optimization processes were determined as 96 mA, 55 s and 28 °C, because these are the centre of the ranges represented by white in Fig. 3. Thus, nickel deposition was performed using these optimum independent variable values. Nickel deposition on graphite electrode were electrochemically characterized by EIS and LSV methods. The hydrogen evolution starts at -0.826 VRHE in 1.0 M KOH according to the Nernst equation. The increase of this potential at cathodic direction is called an overpotential zone. EIS measurements were performed in 1.0 M KOH solution at -0.3 VRHE under the ambient condition to determine catalytic efficiency of electrodes at the overpotential zone. Fig. 4 shows the 3D Nyquist plots of nickel deposited electrodes. The optimization parameters were determined using these plots. Fig. 4 illustrates the different deposition currents (4, 50, and 96 mA) and times (10, 60, and 110 s) at 20°C (Fig. 4a), 30°C (Fig. 4b), and 40°C (Fig. 4c) in 1.0 M KOH. The LSV curves of Ni deposited electrodes by applying 96 mA current during different times (10, 60, and 110 s) and temperatures (20, 30, and 40°C) are shown in Fig. 5 . The LSV curves of 4 mA and 50 mA nickel deposited electrodes were given in Figs. S1 and S2, respectively. The data used in IVER method were determined from the current densities on LSV curves at 0.3 VRHE and 0.5 VRHE overpotential to obtain optimum deposition conditions. According to the results, the optimum conditions were found as 28°C, 55 s and 96 mA for nickel deposition. Fig. 5a and b were given as 3D and 2D views of LSV curves, which were nickel deposited electrodes applying chosen conditions and optimum conditions. It is seen from the figure, the nickel deposited electrode with optimized parameters showed the highest current density at 0.5 V overpotential. It is understood that the optimization technique was achieved. In the second stage of the study, experiment and optimization were performed using the amount of manganese (IV) oxide, which swept with electrochemically deposited nickel on graphite, as the independent variable. Therefore, 3.0, 63.0, 123.0 ppm manganese (IV) oxide were added in the nickel bath while keeping constant the predetermined optimal values (96mA, 55s and 28°C). The aim was maximizing hydrogen evolution currents while minimizing catalyst resistance, again. Optimality curve obtained by the IVER method according to these independent variable values tested as 3.0, 63.0, 123.0 ppm and its histogram equalization applied image representation are shown in Fig. 6 . As can be seen from figure, the optimal independent variable value range represented by white is 51.6–64.3 ppm for manganese (IV) oxide amount. According to this result, it is advised that the optimal manganese (IV) oxide amount was determined as 52 ppm (centre of the white in Fig. 6.), which is advised to use the minimum amount of MnO2. But there is no efficiency difference between 52 and 63 ppm. Therefore, we continued the Molybdenum deposition on Ni*MnO2 electrode prepared with 63 ppm. Fig. 7 shows the Nyquist plots at -0.3 VRHE overpotential of electrodes, in which MnO2 was swept during nickel deposition. According to the results, the resistance increased with added MnO2 excluding deposited at nickel bath containing 63.0 ppm MnO2. The lowest resistance was obtained using 63.0 ppm MnO2. Fig. 8 illustrated the LSV results of MnO2 swept nickel electrodes at the overpotential zone for HER at a 1.0 V s−1 scan rate. The nickel deposited electrode in 63 ppm MnO2 added nickel bath shows higher current densities at -0.3 and -0.5 V compared to the Opt_Ni electrode while they show the same onset potential for hydrogen evolution. The optimum amount found with the IVER method is compatible with EIS and LSV results for MnO2 swept nickel electrodes. Similar experiments and optimization were performed again for molybdenum to determine the optimal deposition time of molybdenum on Ni*MnO2 electrodes. EIS and LSV analysis were performed to determine the best molybdenum deposition time for HER catalysis. These results were given in Figs. S3 and S4. According to the electrochemical analysis results, 5 and 25 min Mo deposited Ni*MnO2 electrode had higher catalytic efficiency compared to 45 min deposition. To define the optimum deposition time, EIS and LSV data were used in the IVER method. In this experiment, the independent variable value is deposition time for molybdenum. Three deposition time were tested for molybdenum. The aim was maximizing hydrogen evolution currents while minimizing impedance, again. The optimization curve obtained by the IVER method, and its histogram equalization applied image representation are shown in the Fig. 9 . The curve and image in the Fig. 9 were obtained according to the tested amounts of molybdenum (5, 25 and 45 min), according to to the 3k FFD method. As can be seen from Fig. 9, the optimal independent variable value range is 7.64–16.47 min for molybdenum deposition time on Ni*MnO2 electrodes. Therefore, the optimal molybdenum deposition time was determined as 12.04 min (centre of the range 7.64–16.47 min). After molybdenum deposition time, platinum was deposited on Ni*MnO2/MoO2 electrode at 1 mA for 45 s at room temperature. 160 µg cm−2 (calculated by Faraday laws) of the platinum was deposited at these parameters. When we think about the commercial price of platinum, 160 µg is so cheap cost for a novel, efficient catalyst. Fig. 10 gives the impedance results at -0.3 V overpotential of whole prepared electrodes and the commercial Pt/C (0.5 mg cm−2 %40 Pt) electrode to obviously see the change. The impedance results at 0.3 V overpotential gives the charge transfer resistance of catalysts while occurring the HER. According to the Nyquist results, 45 s platinum deposited catalyst has smaller resistance compared to commercial Pt/C electrode. LSV measurements for prepared electrodes and commercial 0.5 mg cm−2 %40 Pt/C electrode were performed in the range of 0 to -0.5 VRHE overpotential at 1.0 mV s−1 scan rate (Fig. 11 ). After 160 µg cm−2 of platinum deposition on the Ni*MnO2/MoO2 electrode, the hydrogen evolution onset potential decreased sharply and current densities increased tremendously. Fig. 12 shows the SEM pictograms at 2.5 kx magnitude of prepared catalyst. The messy and porous graphite surface is seen in Fig. 12a. After nickel deposition on graphite, the nickel particles in the range of 1–5 µm closed the graphite surface (Fig. 12b). When MnO2 added nickel deposited on graphite electrode, more porous structure occurred on the surface compared to nickel electrode in Fig. 12c. After molybdenum deposition on Ni*MnO2 electrode, MoO2 nanoparticles seen on surface and surface morphology changed according to Ni*MnO2 electrode in Fig. 12d. And the last step is platinum deposition on Ni*MnO2/MoO2 electrode in Fig. 12e. The spherical white particles occurred on the surface after platinum deposition. Fig. 12f shows the mapping result of the Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrode surface and elemental analysis of electrode materials (w/w%). According to the mapping result, deposited materials were dispersed on the surface homogeneously. Elemental results gave the percentage of C, O, Mo, Mn, Ni, and Pt as 7, 12, 40, 2, 32, 6, respectively. The elemental analysis was performed for the Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrode and shown in Fig. 13 . The XRD result of Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrode was obtained in the range of 10° to 90°. The electrode name was chosen according to Tables 2 and 3 . It is understood that the graphite surface was not seen and the whole electrode occurred by metal-metal oxide composites. The specific peaks for Ni(2p3/2) in the Ni metal spectra at 853 eV [32], Mn(2p3/2) in the MnO2 spectra at 641.9, 642.92, 643.75 eV [33], Mo(3d) in the MoO2 spectra at 231 eV [34] are shown in Fig. 14 . According to these spectra, Ni, MnO2 and MoO2 deposited well on the graphite electrode. Platinum was not seen in the XPS analysis due to trace amount of deposition Fig. 15 . The low frequency carbon-carbon (C-C) vibrations were seen at around 800 cm−1. The low Raman shifts in the range of 100–400 cm−1 proves heavy atoms (like manganese, molybdenum and nickel) vibration and broad peaks explained the semi crystalline structure. 4 Conclusion Ni, Ni*MnO2, Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrodes were prepared by using electrochemical deposition method on graphite supporting material and electrodes’ characterizations and surface morphologies were determined. The optimization results showed that the best deposition conditions are 96 mA, 55 s and 28 °C for Ni, 52 ppm for MnO2 and 12.04 min with 1 mA cm−2 current density for MoO2. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy results showed that the Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrode has the lowest charge resistances. It is understood from this result Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrode has the highest potential for hydrogen evolution. The LSV results show that the Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrode have lower overpotential and higher catalytic efficiency compare the commercial Pt/C electrode. The electrodes were characterized by SEM, EDX, XPS, Raman and XRD analysis. The obtained results explain that the Ni*MnO2/MoO2@Pt electrode were prepared well. coredata.dc:description: Catalyst development is an important process because it affects all dynamics of systems. Optimum values cannot be found easily while catalyst preparation. Input Variable Effect on Responses (IVER) is a very new multi-objective optimization method. It has been developed to eliminate the disadvantages of the Response Surface Method (RSM). The electrolysis of water is known as green hydrogen production and prevents environmental pollution. Studies have focused on the development of effective anodic and cathodic catalysts to reduce the production cost, which is the biggest handicap of this method. In this study, MnO2 swept by nickel is electrochemically deposited on the graphite-supported material to develop an efficient cathode material. Then, MoO2 and Pt electrochemical deposition are carried out, respectively. The optimal electrochemical deposition current, temperature, and time values for the suspended solution concentration are determined using the IVER optimization method. Consequently, the determined optimal (most efficient) suspended solution concentration for MnO2 was 52 ppm, and the most effective deposition condition for Ni is obtained at 28°C, 96 mA, and 55 s. The electrochemical analyzes of the obtained catalysts are carried out by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and linear sweep voltammetry methods. The surface characterizations of these catalysts are carried out using scanning electron microscope-energy-disperse X-ray, XPS, Raman and X-ray diffractometers techniques.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of green hydrogen catalyst with multi-objective optimization
